ratings.comment:
Ann O'Brien, what does she even do? 

She runs a "reverse classroom", which means she doesn't lecture. Does she grade? No. She directs students with tech questions to ask each other, instead of her, because she doesn't have the knowledge to answer.  I hope she retires and is replaced by someone with the expertise + motivation to teach this class.

Ann O'Brien is one of the most incompetent people ever. She gives insane amounts of busy work to avoid having to actually teach or provide material that is of value. She is truly giving this university a bad reputation. She knows little about any sort of accounting or taxes which is crazy considering this is an accounting class.

Get ready for busy work. Ann doesn't know what she is teaching about. She's so lazy that she gives projects so she doesn't actually have to teach. The projects are so tedious that you don't see any value in it. She thinks she is guiding people towards success so I don't think this course will be revised in the future. This class was a waste of time

Ann O'Brien may just be the worst professor I've had. She brought no value to this class rather had students giving presentations on the material, brought in guest speakers to teach, and had graders grading assignments. Someone so technologically challenged should not be teaching a course that is largely technology based.

Ann O'Brien's lectures lacked substance, and the class felt like busy work. Poorly explained, tedious projects offered no value and only caused stress. Ann's limited understanding of the material hinders learning, making this one of the worst classes. She risks damaging appreciation for data analytics, vital to accounting's future. Avoid if you can

This class was torture. There were seven projects that were tedious, time consuming, and extremely stressful. Exams test the understand of specific details rather than a general understanding of subject matter. Ann is an awful instructor and there is no book. I didn't learn anything in this class, and hope this material won't be on the CPA exams.
She has a very different teaching style than most other profs and it just didn't work out for me. I don't like all the theoretical content on exams for a mostly practical class.

She doesn't seem to be competent in the topic that she teaches. She also bounces all over during lecture, which makes it hard to understand the content. The information is interesting, but she makes it boring.

Horrible lectures, super boring, makes interesting course content the least interesting thing in the world. Computer projects are cool but time consuming. Lecture time is worthless. I'd skip class but she counts attendance.

Ann is a great professor and cares a lot about her students. She gets a bad reputation because her class is not structured like other classes - you need to actually have an understanding of the material instead of memorizing it. You also learn by doing things, so her lectures may not always be clear until the topics are done in practice.

Ann's material and learning outcomes was up to date and very interesting. I have already been able to take advantage of the FC skills I learned from her class. I also felt that the things I learned during her class are things that will be beneficial when applying for my first job, example experience of ERP systems and excel functions.

Ann is a great professor. She really cares about helping her students understand the material and offers great assignments that aid in this. However some of the assignments were quite tedious and only worth 1 point. She tries to set up material in an organized manner, however I found it a bit jumbled and hard to navigate.

A caring professor. Lectures mainly focus on the most difficult part of the materials. Despite the diifficulty and complexity of AIS301 coursework, Professor O'Brien manages to deliver the knowledge right, through well-organized notes and fully accessible office hours.

Ann is a great professor! It is clear that she is passionate about the subject and genuinely cares about how her students learn and retain the materials. She is also great at explaining complex issues and establishing interrelationships between topics, which makes the course materials very relevant to real-life applications.

Ann is a very nice lady, and truly cares about her students. However, every class, all she does is run through practice problems expecting that you already have a deep understanding of the material. She expects you to learn a lot, very fast, and assumes you know almost everything from the chapters. Take this class online if you're a finance major.

Ann is a horrible professor but unfortunately there is no one else to take 340 with. The class has too much busy-work that isn't worth the time for the small-portion of your grade it consists of. The curve doesn't help and she seems to favor certain students. I can't tell you how to succeed in this class.. just get through it.

Ann cares about her students and is very knowledgable about accounting . However, whoever came up with this course plan has no concept of student's time. Projects over summer and right before and after exams makes this class terrible. Take easy classes while taking AIS340. Unrealistic workload. Frustration is directed towards Ann but not her fault.

I've had Ann for two semesters in a row now. 301 with her was a hard class. But, now with 340, she was wonderful. Systems is a hard class, filled with 5 computer projects and tricky multiple choice exams. HW is graded on pass/fail basis. Ann does care about her students. This class is unique within the accounting department

Ann is a very nice lady, so I don't take pleasure in writing this; she shouldn't be teaching anymore. Her expectations aren't clear for quizzes, case studies, or tests, so your grade will suffer. She lacks basic organization skills which makes her mandatory lectures pointless. Avoid her class if you can. If you can't, make sure you read the book.

I feel like Ann taught me nothing over the entire semester. I learned everything myself. The first two exams are math heavy, and the last one is all about concepts. Going to the lectures seems like a big waste of time, and she doesn't clarify how she grades your participation. Sincere advise: try to avoid her if possible!

I found the class both interesting and frustrating. I understand that we need to teach ourselves software programs, but she could do a better job setting us up for success. Her PPTs are a mess, her examples are from before 2000, and her course packet is riddled with errors. She is very nice and really cares, the curriculum just needs some updates.

Awesome! O'Brien designed AIS340 to cover the most relevant professional software with a well designed progression of skills. She teaches us how to learn, a really invaluable skill. (That seems to be missed by other reviewers and taken negatively.) O'Brien's projects are interesting and incorporate current career topics. I love the active learning!

Great professor! she balanced in class learning experience with direct teaching and assigned projects. The assigned projects simulated real work situation where one learns how to learn to be successful. The professor showed empathy with students, she sincerely cared for her students and she was always available outside of class to help students.

She was an incredible professor! From the beginning of the course when I sensed myself struggling, she spent time helping me and showed she truly cared that I did well, but more importantly, learned. Her class is structured excellently given the nature of a course on acct systems. Highly recommend everyone takes at least one class with her!

Don't be fooled by the absence of an attendance policy: if you're not in class, Ann will do everything she can to make sure you struggle to make it up and dock points. A condescending instructor, just make sure you get on her good side early. Your performance here is not nearly as important as her opinion of you as a student.
The worst

Materials are easy to understand and applicable to workplace, but this class has a lot of stupid tiny assignments that take you a lot of time. Got a computer project due before class even started this semester. Ridiculous
One of the best professors I had. She has a passion for what she does and actually cares about her students' well-being and learning. The class was extremely applicable to the profession as well.

By far the most incompetent, least favorite classprofessor of all times. If she doesn't even know how to do flowchart, what gives her the right to teach? I get that this info system class is necessary for accounting students but boy lectures are so repetitive and painful as it can get. So many assignments and exams are ridiculous.

O'Brien is by far the worst "teacher" I've had at Madison. I use quotes around teacher because she skips through the slides in class saying we can read them later. I learned more about the material from google and youtube than from being in class. She's extremely disrespectful to the students she doesn't like, and doesn't try to hide it. AVOID!

Ann O'Brien is a wonderful teacher stuck with the impossible task of teaching WSoB students everything there is to know about systems. She offers valuable insight into some of the more common systems (NetSuite, SAP), as well as essential business softwares (Excel, Access). Professor O'Brien knows the material and teaches with a hands-on approach.

Worst professor I've had. An embarrassment to the business school. She makes it very clear from the beginning she is NOT a source to help you, & her advice to passing is to either google it or ask a classmate.  We should get paid to make it through that class.  I've taken art classes that have been more beneficial.  AVOID AT ALL COSTS.

Not much is taught in the course. Rely on random guessing because the things you  "learned" are not really tested but a bunch of random stuff here and there.  What I got out of the class could have been taught in 5 lectures.

I took this class a year ago, but it's stuck out in my mind because it helped tie a lot of business classes together for me. You can tell Professor O'Brien really cares about her students and wants to see them succeed in the class and in the real world too. Don't be afraid to ask for clarification either because she's always willing to help out!

Worst teacher I've met all through my college years. Pretend to care about student, but actually don't give a sh*t. Always fake smiling to you, which is disgusting. Totally no use to attend the lecture, but she will threats you with grade if you don't come. There is no guidance, no help for all the tests. Avoid this witch as soon as possible!

Not a great class overall. TEDIOUS cases, tests were OK. Ann does her best to keep things moving, because she knows that people tune out quickly. You can tell she cares that students understand the importance of what's really going on. Helpfulness was questionable, sometimes gave clear explanations and others "that's just the way it is." Blah prof.

Very nice and helpful professor! 340 has a lot of busywork and detailed projects but they are very beneficial for jobs/interviews after college. If you attend class & pay attention there is no reason you shouldn't get an A. Ann makes sure you get a lot of practice and know the material well.  She genuinely cares, and I would recommend her!

Professor O'Brien is the nicest woman I have ever met. She goes above and beyond for the accounting program and really tries to teach in a way that avoids boring powerpoint lecture slides. She strives to have the students learn to teach different systems to themselves, which will be helpful in the long run, but she is still available for questions.

She doesn't seem to know the subject she is teaching, so she can't explain the ambiguity of her own assignments. Don't expect to get any help from her. Grading is completely arbitrary. Sad as this class should be interesting and great but it's not. AOB is nice but shouldn't be teaching at a fine business school like UW-Madison.

Ann is a great teacher who genuinely cares about student understanding & interest in the material.  Employs a good blend of textbook material and experiential learning through software projects.  She's very clear about interrelationships of topics, and IT & accounting in general.  Provides a lot of opportunities to learn.  Good experience!
Very nice and helpful teacher!  It's a difficult class to teach, but she does a great job of teaching it in an interesting way.  Lots of busy work which is expected when learning new software.

Class was very beneficial. Learned a lot. She is very concerned with student understanding and will help you figure things out. Explains material very clear and loves this subject. I recommend her to any student of any major.
A nice person!!

She really cares about you learning the material.  A very nice teacher.  Has lots of insight for students.  Out of class work consists of computer projects but she also devotes some lab time to work on projects in class.
Very nice, helpful teacher. She cares about the material. Lots of projects and homework
She is a very hands off professor and expects you to do a lot of learning outside of class. Class time is boring and the projects seem easy but are graded very detailed.

A very nice lady.  She knows a lot about accounting and is very passionate about it and applying it to the real world.  Her tests were all self-written and it seemed like she never took them herself after writing them because half the questions were unanswerable (not enough info). However, she often gave points to all for her mistakes.

This is the first semester for her teaching this class and you can tell she really cares about the material.  AOB is a great person and wonderful to talk to or get advice from, she just doesn't always structure class time very well.  Also is vague on requirements for class and switched to accuracy grading on hwk halfway through semester.

She is very nice and helpful...encourages participation but it's not required for a grade. Make sure to attend lecture and keep up with the homework (15%). The projects are useful in terms of learning real world application software, and if you're grade is oddly low, submit it for a regrade or talk to the TA grading the projects. Tests are not hard
